b) we have allies and
c) we now understand

3263.05.text:
that without the security
element being

3266.25.text:
in the correct place it's
impossible to do anything else.

3271.15.text:
I mean my instinct about this is
though is that we've got to --

3276.22.text:
, this is why I say we've got to
look upon this in a different way.

3279.83.text:
If we are expecting a quick
result and a clean sort

3283.83.text:
of okay now that's done, I
think we are kidding ourselves

3288.98.text:
but I think sustained
engagement over a period

3293.62.text:
of time though difficult is
preferable to a vacuum that is going

3300.35.text:
to be filled by either extremists
or other interests and powers

3305.57.text:
that may have an agenda
completely contrary to our own

3309.50.text:
and therefore I suppose what I
think ultimately is the difficulty

3318.09.text:
of doing it is not as great as the
danger of not doing it but I say

3326.91.text:
to people all the time
this is really difficult.

3332.25.text:
to you I think a lot would say
we did that, we went in there

3338.48.text:
and we tried to rebuild Iraq and
we tried to rebuild Afghanistan

3342.02.text:
and we spent a huge amount of
American blood and British blood

3348.80.text:
and treasure, trillions of
dollars, and it didn't work

3355.04.text:
so why do you think it
can work this time around?

3359.89.text:
Just because we know
better how to do it?

3362.41.text:
>> I think partly but I think
also because you've always got

3366.01.text:
to ask the question,
the counterfactual,

3369.20.text:
so I mean leave aside Iraq
from being more controversial

3375.95.text: in this sentence but if you look

3378.03.text:
at Afghanistan it would really
be better if we had done nothing

3383.48.text:
or if we hadn't tried
to do that building.

3386.42.text:
You see when we were fighting
the Cold War and if you'd said

3392.05.text:
to somebody in the 70s or 80s well
you're spending all this money

3397.94.text:
but you would've said well I'm
afraid were going to do it and I --

3404.78.text:
, it all depends how you
identify the problem.

3407.76.text:
If the problem is violent
extremism, a group of fanatics,

3417.33.text:
>> Yes, but if it isn't
and it's broader

3420.08.text:
than that then I think you do have
to try and defeat it completely

3426.29.text:
and so I think so much of
the policy consequence flows

3436.62.text:
I always say to people I've
approach to this with huge humility

3441.31.text:
and I think it's a poor [inaudible]
to get into who is responsible

3449.63.text:
for this or that or whatever but
I think we've got to try in a way

3456.68.text:
to say well what really
have we learned from 2001?

3460.67.text:
Now if we've decided we've
learned is we should stay

3463.55.text:
out of everything I would
argue that Syria shows you

3466.61.text:
that that's not a great strategy
either and maybe what we can do,

3472.30.text:
and this is what I was
arguing in my remarks,

3474.58.text:
is you can actually synthesize
those two periods of policymaking

3480.38.text:
and construct a policy of active
engagement with allies that is

3486.84.text:
as I said sophisticated by our
experience and not incapacitated

3490.81.text:
by it but I can't see myself that
we've got an option in the end

3497.26.text:
and by the way we've talked
a lot about the Middle East

3499.86.text:
but in my view the single
biggest threat sub-Saharan Africa

3503.73.text:
in development terms today
could be this extremism.

3506.68.text:
In countries like Kenya I mean this
is absolutely existential for them.

3512.80.text:
You have a country like
Somalia or Mali or [inaudible]

3517.17.text:
in northern Nigeria, now you
look at how we deal with that

3522.65.text:
but you've already got now almost
three million people displaced

3526.56.text:
in northern Nigeria so I think
one of the things I also say

3531.46.text:
to Europeans is we've got to look
at our own responsibilities here

3535.27.text:
because you guys are a long
way away from all this.

3538.82.text:
Now you're still America so you're
still the big power and we need you

3542.77.text: but you know we in Europe why

3545.78.text:
if you've got these Syrian
refugees how could we say no

3549.53.text:
to the refugees coming
from northern Africa

3553.54.text:
or the northern part
of sub-Saharan Africa?

3557.76.text: >> We have time for two more.

3559.06.text:
The first is actually a
question about Lebanon,

3562.96.text:
it's role in the conflict
and the probability

3568.67.text:
>> I think people are right to
be very worried about Lebanon

3572.36.text:
and it's a tragedy for the
country, it's a great country,

3575.77.text:
fantastic people but you know
it's the same issue isn't it?

3582.11.text:
They are kept in a permanent state
of destabilization by Hezbollah

3586.19.text:
and Iran and that's why I
think one of the things we have

3592.48.text:
to do is we have to be pushing back
against that power very strongly.

3603.59.text:
to destabilize it would
have a serious impact

3605.71.text:
on the whole region
including obviously on Israel.

3609.13.text:
>> You know it's interesting
that this is the first time

3613.69.text:
that Iran has entered
into our discussion

3615.68.text:
which would not have been the case I
think before the Iran nuclear deal.

3624.38.text:
It's kind of taken the wind out
of their argument in a strange way

3630.70.text:
but is Iran part of the problem or
part of the solution when it comes

3637.38.text: >> Well at the moment for the region

3641.34.text:
as a whole it's a destabilizing
influence.

3646.14.text:
Now can they be persuaded or
can there be change within Iran

3654.87.text:
that allows those people who
obviously have a different

3657.58.text:
and more moderate view,
can we get to a stage

3662.13.text:
where that strain of
thinking prevails?

3668.42.text:
But if you look at the activities of
Iran and whether in Lebanon or Syria

3677.83.text:
or Yemen or the attempts to
destabilize the Gulf states,

3683.12.text:
even attempts to get support within
Hamas, I mean I find it hard to look

3689.69.text:
at Iran's influence in the
region and see it positively.

3696.11.text:
>> The final question is on Northern
Ireland and the peace process

3700.34.text:
and whether there are parallels
or lessons from your experience

3703.65.text:
that could be applied
to the Middle East.

3710.17.text:
>> There are some but
we were very fortunate

3714.55.text:
in the Northern Ireland
process of having leadership

3718.12.text:
on virtually every side that really
wanted to do things and was prepared

3723.03.text:
to be quite brave with
their end support.

3733.67.text:
You know we had a good constellation
of leaders at that time

3742.38.text:
I mean one is that you have to
get a framework that is fair.

3745.67.text:
The second is you will spend
long time implementing it.

3749.64.text:
The third is never to
give up and I still think

3756.02.text:
in the Middle East peace
process we should never give up.

3758.55.text:
I fear that personal
consequences of carrying on my head

3765.46.text:
against that brick wall
but the other great factor

3768.17.text:
in Northern Ireland was the
spirit of the Irish obviously

3771.05.text:
and I remember what we used
to do in Northern Ireland is

3782.44.text:
when we hit a logjam in a
negotiation we'd take the Irish

3789.82.text:
and the different parties all the
way for a sort of weekend kind

3793.93.text:
of brainstorm and get
everyone back on track again -

3798.02.text:
>> Right, I was putting that
more diplomatically [laughter],

3803.55.text:
but I remember there
was an occasion in 1999

3808.71.text:
when my wife was then pregnant
with our child who was born

3815.82.text:
on Downing Street and
during the course of one

3819.54.text:
of these weekends away
one of the delegation

3823.59.text: from Northern Ireland came up to me

3825.29.text:
and said congratulations Prime
Minister, it's a wonderful thing,

3828.53.text:
you know your wife
is expecting a baby

3831.08.text:
and he said what do you
think you will call it?

3834.28.text: And I said well I don't know I think

3836.19.text:
if it's a boy I think I'll
call it after my father, Leo.

3840.99.text:
And he said oh that's a lovely
thought, that's a lovely thought.

3844.88.text:
Anyway, my wife gave birth,
we were away a month later

3850.31.text:
and I saw this guy again and
he had a fantastic suntan.

3854.83.text:
Now I don't know whether you've
ever been to Northern Ireland

3857.94.text:
but [laughter], there's many great
things about Northern Ireland

3861.26.text:
but you're not liable to come
away with a suntan so I said

3863.90.text:
to him my God you look fantastic,
where did you get that suntan from?

3868.36.text:
And he said well actually
you're responsible for.

3870.41.text: I said I'm responsible for it?

3872.30.text:
He said yes remember that
conversation I had when I asked

3875.00.text:
about your wife being
pregnant and I asked

3876.95.text: about what you might call the child?

3880.08.text:
He said well the next day I
went down to the bookmakers

3882.73.text:
and put 1000 pounds on
the name of the child -

3892.05.text:
So that was another major reason
why it succeeded [laughter].

3897.83.text:
>> Ladies and gentlemen I think we
should thank Tony Blair very much

3906.76.text:
>> This has been a presentation
of the Library of Congress.
